urls.title: Sold a Story: How Teaching Kids to Read Went So Wrong
urls.description: There's an idea about how children learn to read that's held sway in schools for more than a generation — even though it was proven wrong by cognitive scientists decades ago. Teaching methods based on this idea can make it harder for children to learn how to read. In this new podcast, host Emily Hanford investigates the influential authors who promote this idea and the company that sells their work. It's an expose of how educators came to believe in something that isn't true and are now reckoning with the consequences — children harmed, money wasted, an education system upended.

data.text:
Sold a Story: How Teaching Kids to Read Went So Wrong

https://t.co/2txJCn59PL

But something needs to be done right away. I worry that in 10 or 20 years we’ll  end up with another serial podcast from American Public Media about how progressive educational philosophies failed half of a generation – except this time it’ll be about math instead of reading.

The former problem is more intractable than the latter. The problem of courage can at least potentially be addressed by those individuals seeking out the tools to have tough conversations and developing courage within themselves.

I worry that there are two big problems explaining why it doesn’t happen. One, leadership may be aligned with the ideology. Two, leadership may not have the courage to address it for fear of being called racist, a colonizer, white supremacist, etc.
They needn’t be berated or publicly called out. But hard conversations need to be had by folks in positions to have them (leadership).

And people with that aim are not primarily concerned that kids develop certain competencies to become fully functioning adults.

They’re committing  edugenic harm and it should be addressed by people who know better.

She pushes that because she believes that anything from the dominant culture is wrong in some cosmic, pseudo-religious, sense. 

When I say she’s lost the plot, I mean that her aim is not student learning. It’s something else. It’s decolonization or some related idea.

Is that method of counting intrinsically True or the universal “best” way? 

Of course not. 

But that teacher wasn’t making a pedagogical choice in an effort to develop number sense.

But when you’re trying to teach number sense and you and your students live in a culture that counts in a particular way – and you care about the kids actually learning number sense – you should stick to that way.

Of course we should fix systemic problems where possible. But much of that is outside of their control. So the message has to be that they have the power to improve their lives by the decisions that they make and how they respond to setbacks.
If we want our kids to feel empowered, and not slip into nihilism, then those of us who work with young people can't embrace a worldview that tells a hopeless story about their lives.

The implicit, or sometimes explicit, message that that which causes your life to be bad is out of your control and can only improve if enough ppl decide to upend the current systems, is incredibly disempowering (and not true).
This is why I'm concerned with the rhetoric on the left, especially to young people.

In Stoicism the ability to locate and focus on what you can control, and not worrying about the rest, is key to living a meaningful, happy, life. 

A tremendous amount of misery stems from worrying about that which is out of our control – or trying to control it.
Look, if we’re gonna compete at something, we’re gonna go hard. https://t.co/4ewny8D9Xc

RT @LetGrowOrg: CHOPPING, HOPPING, MOWING, GOING, GROWING: These kids entered the 2022 LET GROW INDEPENDENCE CHALLENGE!
Did YOU do these th…

Did your teacher-prep program prepare you to teach kids how to think? 
* What makes a good teacher?  
* What is learning?
* What’s a *real* safe space in the classroom?

Are we just pushing our own ideology? 
* What’s the elevator pitch for the curriculum? 
* What’s one activity you would use to give people a sense of the curriculum?
* How do you anticipate this curriculum fitting into the rigid structure of schooling?

*Why did we develop the curriculum?
* Problems with teacher education programs
* How is the curriculum intended to be used and by whom?
* Can critical thinking be taught? 
* Can (or should) we trust teachers?

urls.title: Do growth mindset interventions impact students’ academic achievement? A systematic review and meta-analysis with recommendations for best practices.
urls.description: According to mindset theory, students who believe their personal characteristics can change—that is, those who hold a growth mindset—will achieve more than students who believe their characteristics are fixed. Proponents of the theory have developed interventions to influence students’ mindsets, claiming that these interventions lead to large gains in academic achievement. Despite their popularity, the evidence for growth mindset intervention benefits has not been systematically evaluated considering both the quantity and quality of the evidence. Here, we provide such a review by (a) evaluating empirical studies’ adherence to a set of best practices essential for drawing causal conclusions and (b) conducting three meta-analyses. When examining all studies (63 studies, N = 97,672), we found major shortcomings in study design, analysis, and reporting, and suggestions of researcher and publication bias: Authors with a financial incentive to report positive findings published significantly

tweets.text: “[A]pparent effects of growth mindset interventions on academic achievement are likely attributable to inadequate study design, reporting flaws, and bias.” https://t.co/jfslKa5pzX https://t.co/3xibDjczSk

urls.title: ‎Honestly with Bari Weiss: Why We Must Save Our Boys on Apple Podcasts
urls.description: ‎Show Honestly with Bari Weiss, Ep Why We Must Save Our Boys - Oct 19, 2022

tweets.text:
My chat on @bariweiss' Honestly w @richardvreeves, author of "Of Boys and Men" on why he wrote a book everyone told him he shouldn't. Men's issues in 2022? Asking for trouble. But the numbers are scary for our men & boys, & we should care about them:

https://t.co/Qc4J29i4Rg
@z_cress That's powerful.
@z_cress Beautifully said. And a much needed message. (You would enjoy the @EconTalker podcast, btw. Go back and find some that look interesting over the past couple of years)
If we want our kids to feel empowered, and not slip into nihilism, then those of us who work with young people can't embrace a worldview that tells a hopeless story about their lives.

The implicit, or sometimes explicit, message that that which causes your life to be bad is out of your control and can only improve if enough ppl decide to upend the current systems, is incredibly disempowering (and not true).
This is why I'm concerned with the rhetoric on the left, especially to young people.

In Stoicism the ability to locate and focus on what you can control, and not worrying about the rest, is key to living a meaningful, happy, life. 

A tremendous amount of misery stems from worrying about that which is out of our control – or trying to control it.

Global antidepressant use by country.

USA number one. https://t.co/GJyfcBbLLI

urls.title: Homepage
urls.description: At Let Grow, we believe kids are smarter and safer than our culture gives them credit for. Therefore, through school programs, parent empowerment, research and advocacy, we are making it easy, normal and legal to give kids back some of childhood's rocket fuel: independence.

tweets.text:
CHOPPING, HOPPING, MOWING, GOING, GROWING: These kids entered the 2022 LET GROW INDEPENDENCE CHALLENGE!
Did YOU do these things as a kid? 
Are your kids doing them now? 
Discuss! And visit https://t.co/joP1i34dVn to see the whole video! https://t.co/Bc9YxMB0Sd

Are we just pushing our own ideology? 
* What’s the elevator pitch for the curriculum? 
* What’s one activity you would use to give people a sense of the curriculum?
* How do you anticipate this curriculum fitting into the rigid structure of schooling?

*Why did we develop the curriculum?
* Problems with teacher education programs
* How is the curriculum intended to be used and by whom?
* Can critical thinking be taught? 
* Can (or should) we trust teachers?

urls.title: The TeachThought Podcast Ep. 306 Creating A Critical Thinking Curriculum - TeachThought PD
urls.description: Drew Perkins talks with Will Reusch and Zach Cresswell about the Critical Thinking Across the Disciplines curriculum they’ve created and are piloting with funding through Heterodox Academy.

tweets.text:
Had a great time talking with @dperkinsed about the curriculum, “Critical Thinking Across the Disciplines,” that @teecherreusch and I developed!

Give it a listen and share widely! #edchat #miched #mtbos #criticalthinking 

https://t.co/IODWP2JWHp

In the podcast we discuss:

Don’t teach function composition without also teaching function decomposition.

“Going backwards” or “undoing” actions is an interesting theme throughout math that’s worth revisiting whenever you can.
#iteachmath

urls.title: Couch: 3 quick takes on Michigan State's 34-28 double-overtime win over Wisconsin
urls.description: Lansing State Journal columnist Graham Couch gives his initial thoughts on the Spartans' performance against the Badgers with his 3 quick takes

Lansing State Journal columnist Graham Couch gives his initial thoughts on the Spartans' performance against the Badgers with his 3 quick takes.
 https://t.co/S2u8KgzTG8

More than 25 million people use Google Docs.

But most of us still don't know its best features.

Here are 11 Google Docs tips that'll save you 100s of hours of your life:

Being a kid today is like being a race car only allowed to go 20 mph. So many kids are not allowed to do ANYTHING (esp play outside) w/out an adult watching, cautioning. Some have never built a fort or walked to a friend's alone. SAFETY is the only thing in their lives.

DISCUSS!

tweets.text:
I talked recently with @teecherreusch and @z_cress about their very interesting Critical Thinking Across the Disciplines pilot curriculum funded by @HdxAcademy. 

The @TeachThought Podcast Ep. 306 Creating A Critical Thinking Curriculum https://t.co/L93FX6pzB2 via @TeachThoughtPD https://t.co/VKiVklaYoL
